comments.commentBody: If you REALLY care that deeply for the majestic plants then consider the number of plants killed to fatten the cows which you will then eat...

Karzai has asked us to leave and we should simply say OK, pack up and leave.  There are lots of arguments that would be made against a sudden withdrawl, but 10 years from now it would be the same as if we left gradually except that there would be fewer of our young people killed and maimed and billions saved.

More young Americans died in Vietnam after Nixon's "Peace with Honor" pledge than before.

The lessons of Vietnam were quickly forgotten or twisted cynically into a claim that we could have won if we only used our military power with more force -- as if dropping more bombs on Vietnam than axis and allied troops dropped on Europe during WWII was not enough military power.

I fully expect we will once again hear justifications for losing Afghanistan and Iraq following these same lines. We lost these two wars (or at least did not get the democracies we fought for) because we did not use full military force.

We Americans can't seem to get it through our thick skulls that military force can not affect the changes we want. As in the case of Vietnam, afterwar economic forces did more to open that country up and turn it into an American ally than all the bombing could possibly have done. War is never the solution; it always remains the problem.

Let's hope that no presidential candidate makes a "Peace with Honor" pledge like Nixon did in1968, with the result that thousands more died in a war where decisive military victory was never a realistic goal.

Our primary legitimate reason for the Afghan War terminated when Bin Laden was eliminated. "Mission Accomplished", now let's leave. And let's hope that the military runs the other way when some neocon trots out his copy of the Project for the New American Century.

I strongly urge anyone who finds all this confusing to read the book!  Dr's Nestle and Nesheim do a remarkable job of making the humble but inscrutable calorie and it's importance to our health accessible to the general reader. Just to be clear, N&N do not recommend that we go around assiduously attempting to count the calories in everything that goes in our mouths. Rather, they offer common sense advice that will help you to lower your overall intake. The most interesting tidbit under the Move More section is the admonition to FIDGET--a strategy backed by science no less!

Too funny...I've never tried either Vegemite or Marmite & really have no urge to (my mother was a clean-your-plate person, so by the time I was 18 I had had my lifetime quota of eating foods I didn't like). I did OD on Nutella as an exchange student in France & haven't touched the stuff since. And it's got to be Peter Pan Extra Crunchy peanut butter. : )

Newt "Two-States" Gingrich should have taken a sleeping pill last week after losing both Alabama and Mississippi.

Meanwhile, he and Callista continue their excellent adventure to nowhere.
It's called mass delusion AAC....that's all.
Rimantas, Obama would only be debating Gingrich if Gingrich were to become the GOP nominee. Every day, that becomes less likely than Newt staying married to wife #3 (and counting).
Sorry, Karen, I'm voting to help my family. My pay's been cut by 100%.

Romney "battle hardened persona"?

Are you talking about the prep school cheerleader Viet Nam draft dodger Willard Romney?

Hardest thing the man ever did was rob people of their jobs and pensions.

SanFranciscoReader is on to something here:  what has poisoned political discourse since 2009 is the rise of  low-information voters, who have neither the time nor the inclination to do their homework about the issues, facts and candidates and thus prefersto accept whatever passes through the filter of their one preferred and trusted source of information--always the source whose beliefs replicate and reinforce their own. Seeking as many competent sources of information and evaluating the agenda prisms through which they are filtered is just too messy and time-consuming.  An "informed populace" needs to be informed by a variety of often conflicting sources.

Annie- totally agree.  My mother ran an office but now even digital thermostats and clocks can be a hassle and politicians think old folks can learn to fight for themselves when these industries are basically predatory?? It is really perverse what the Republican party is proposing for America's seniors.

This "country" is and has for decades, been a military empire, with  bases worldwide on a scale that would make the Roman emperors blush. i am no fan of Ron Paul's but on this point, he makes more sense than almost any other politician including President Obama. Bring them home and rebuild America.

In the immortal words of DeepThroat, "Follow the money"  How many armaments companies are in the US, how big a portion of exportdollars  are from armaments, how much do these companies donate to politicians/superPACs?  Not to mention other companies that really profit from war- the support/supply companies?  I think you'll find the answer there.  Almost all wars involve economics to a large degree.

'But most of the politicians seemed resigned to the fact that President Obama is resigned to settling for a very small footprint and enough troops to keep terrorists from using Afghanistan as a base to attack the U.S. or our allies.'

I wonder just how small that 'footprint' will be, hopefully nothing like the many thousands of military personnel still in Germany and in South Korea.

This country has an obsession with military 'solutions' which never seem to achieve the intended goals and are helping to bankrupt this country. As the young man who lost his leg asked "Why are we still there?"
You will have noticed that no one wants to have a beer with Mitt. Not that he would.

Chris L., I refer you and others to Pres. Obama's West Point speech on Afghanistan for the context of the troop surge.  In a nutshell, he said we would make one final try to achieve a reasonable result in Afghanistan, but that the US has greater priorities and uses for its treasure.  It is safe to assume that he, the secy. of state, and his military advisers are looking at the best options within that strategy.  I, for one, am very happy that we have the level-headed  leadership we do rather than than the jingoistic, war-crazy republicans.
I agree.   Also it's time that we declare war against the stupid and ignorant and rebuild our democracy ruled by the sensible secular, educated majority with common sense in this country.

Americans should never forget that it was George Bush who lied us into the Iraq war and took his eye off the ball in Afghanistan. We must never forget that in spite of the fact that Americans are allergic to history. He also inexplicably did not kill Bin Laden when he had the chance and turned the job hired warlord contact killers who took the money and ran. If not for the intellectually challenged and perpetual adolescent manchild's incompetence, we would never be having this conversation.

If not for the incredibly stupid Americans who thought that they would rather have our nation lead by Incurious George instead of Al Gore or John Kerry, we would not be having that conversation either. Who needs someone with brains as president like Bill Clinton when you can imagine having a cool Coors with 43.

Obama had to promise to escalate in Afghanistan to help him get elected. He tried the surge, killed Bin Laden and eliminated the threat of al-Qaeda . It's time to get out. The entire enterprise is putrefying and decomposing like a cadaver left in the sun right before our very eyes. I think Obama should announce the withdrawal of our troops at the latest mid 2012. He needs to show some boldness and political courage here or he will end being held responsible for whatever calamity lurking. around the corner the longer we stay.

We must also never forget the fact that the Afghanistan war was the inherited from his hapless predecessor. It's time to nation build here at home.

Besides, it not like it was 2000 pages of War and Peace. Those 2000 pages were formatted like a kid in 7th grade does to get a four page essay out of a paragraph - wide-margins and line spacing. Not that this formatting was atypical for a bill, but the repeated use of the "2000 pages" by media was disingenuous at best.

Did we forget how to read?

"We'll have to pass the bill to find out what's in it". Oh! I'm sorry. That's what Nancy Pelosi said about the ACA because not many legislators had read it and the regulations are still being written, so really won't know what's in the whole bill until 2014.

America needs a new understanding of how its monetary and fiscal policy function. We've been lulled into accepting as Galbraith and Mosler posit, Innocent Frauds of Economic Policy. Our lawmakers continue to function as if America was still bound by the gold standard and fixed exchange rates which required taxes to balance the national budget. That no longer applies. Nixon abandoned those principles in August of 1971.

Since then America has had a "sovereign, fiat" monetary and fiscal policy system with the Federal Reserve being the monopoly issuer of the dollar. We no longer convert that dollar to gold and its value is no longer fixed by the value of gold. The Federal Reserve and Treasury collaborate in issuing currency to pay for government's expenditures. They do this irrespective of the level of tax revenue or borrowing authority. Ask anyone in the Federal Reserve Operations Division, they will tell you that they don't use tax revenue to pay for anything. This post-1971 monetary and fiscal policy operation is not constrained by revenue to spend.

In this post-1971 world, taxes serve only to manage aggregate demand. If government and private sector spending overheat the economy, taxes and interest rates can be raised to withdraw dollars from disposable income. Federal taxes then should be maintained at a very low level to serve as a thermostat for the economy not a policy tool for raising revenue.

Same smoke and mirrors as the previous path to prosperity document.  I searched the entire site for information broken down by budget program code and nothing.  Further, he again promises tax reform and tax cuts but I want to see the reforms first and then tax cuts, not like the empty promises previously made by both Democrats and Republicans to cut taxes and then the reforms are forgotten.  Sorry Mr. Ryan, the devil is in the details and your details are missing in action.  If you want our support, a fully laid out budget by department and program code is necessary and a specific list of all the items in the tax code you promise to remove, particularly deductions, credits and all other giveaways listed in detail.  If it takes 2000 pages, so be it.  I took the time to read the affordable care act in its entirety (which many clearly did not) so why can you not provide the same detail with your budget so those of us who actually care about this country can read it for ourselves?

A pretty bland collaboration on this Wednesday, by two constructors, who on their own are well regarded.
THELOT wasn't everything, infact it was just the opposite...Empty!

WHH
It's not just African Americans. I look at pictures of Trayvon and I see someone I would be proud to call my son.
I could agree more with Gates; include 'past and present' along side 'future' .

In the 1960s, Phil Ochs dubbed the United States "the cops of the world" in a satirical song. Someone asked if we had learned anything from Vietnam. Someone asked the question from "Where have all the flowers gone," a Pete Seeger song, based on an old Russian (I think) proverb or saying. Maureen herself calls this effort "Sisyphean." All of these bring make each and every American to tears, because we have not stopped these wars. "Listen to the generals who are on the ground," politicians say. Why? Generals are trained to FIGHT, to go to war. They revel in this.

Instead, I say, listen to the young Marine at Walter Reed: Why are we still there? Why are we the cops of the world? Why are we pushing this rock up this hill? When will we ever learn?

All that marching we did to stop the Vietnam war in the 1960s--what haven't we taken to the streets again?

beethy "When will we realize this?"

Apparently never. How long have we been in Korea? What happened in Vietnam? Um, who can remember?

When Bush was re-elected in 2004 I realized that somehow more than 50% of Americans have lower than average intelligence. It seems statistically impossible, but we have achieved it.

[The epitaph of our Sisyphean decade of two agonizing wars was written last year by then-Secretary of Defense Bob Gates: “Any future defense secretary who advises the president to send a big American land army into Asia, or into the Middle East or Africa, should have his head examined.”] : Maureen

I couldn't agree with Gates more !

Nothing else describes our recent adventures better than 'Sisyphean'.

When will we realize this?

"Here's a hint: taxing the rich won't come close."

Raising taxes on the rich to Clinton-era levels would actually make a significant dent in the deficit. Republicans have managed to convince many people of the opposite by comparing the 1-year revenue from additional taxes to the 10-year budget deficit. If you compare 1-year additional revenues from increased upper-income tax rates to the 1-year total deficit, which is the only meaningful way to do it, you will realize that you've got the facts completely wrong.

If Obama wins it will be a repudiation of GOP extremism which has turned this former now recovering main street moderate country club republican off of this new church party: sanctimonious, intolerant, anti-science, anti-knowledge, anti-women, gay obsessed, indifferent to poverty and injustice, greedy, angry and jealous of Obama.
Some of you folks on the Right give the media way too much credit. It's a strange obsession you have, considering one need only search a little in order to find the "media" that suits one's views.

Romney is like McCain in 2008. A formerly decent man who has lost his bearings because of ambition, and who will say anything, no matter how stupid, to get elected. Look at the most meaningful achievement of his career, namely Romneycare, and note that he's so disoriented that he runs away from it.

Romney would spectacularly underperform his resume if elected, which I suspect will never happen.
Because it wouldn't fit the space and "favourite" is a Brit spelling.

Yes but that is exactly the Ayn Randian dystopia that Mr. Ryan envisions for the country. The strong (makers) would prosper while the weak (takers) would be left to their own devices to struggle to survive.
But makes for low cost worker bees!!! highly profitable for some!!!
Considering that Ms. Rand was a writer of fiction is it any wonder that the Ryan budget is fiction as well without a lot of plot development.
A country full of sick, weak, hungry and dying people is not a strong country.

The Times comment processor apparently eats plus sign symbols, and two are missing from my post from one paragraph. The corrected paragraph should read

"There are 12*11 ways to end up with two reds, and 12*B PLUS B*12 = 24*B ways to end up with one of each color. Two red cards happens in more ways if 12*11 > 24*B, or when B is at most 6. Two reds is the most likely result (more likely than one of each or two blacks) if 12*11 > 24*B PLUS B*(B-1), or when B is 4 or less."

If there are b black cards, and a card is chosen at random, b different choices yield a black card, regardless of the number of reds.

If there are r red cards, and a card is chosen at random, r different choices yield a red card, regardless of the number of blacks.

With B blacks and 12 reds to begin with, the number of choices that yield each color sequence is:

Red, red: 12*11
Red, black: 12*B
Black,black: B*(B-1)
Black, red: B*12

There are 12*11 ways to end up with two reds, and 12*B B*12 = 24*B ways to end up with one of each color. Two red cards happens in more ways if 12*11 > 24*B, or when B is at most 6. Two reds is the most likely result (more likely than one of each or two blacks) if 12*11 > 24*B B*(B-1), or when B is 4 or less.

The total number of ways the second card can be chosen doesn't depend on the first card's color, and at each step the possible choices are equally likely, so counting and comparing numbers of choices (instead of probabilities) is sufficient to answer the question.

Summarizing, with 12 red cards, the outcome will be two reds more often than one of each if there are at most six black cards to begin with. Two red cards result more than half the time if there are at most four black cards to begin with.

In the question, two cards were chosen together, not sequentially. Choosing sequentially doesn't change the results, because each pair can be chosen in exactly two ways. Making the choices sequentially favors no pair over another.

The junior college that denied Newton Gingrich tenure and forced him out is right west of us beyond the Okeefenokee Swamp, called West Georgia Junior College.  A lot of kids went to West Georgia Junior College hoping if they worked hard they'd get to move up to Georgia State or even Georgia Tech.  Newton is a big joke down here.
